title: Comments on Griffith's and Prager's Peterson Videos
description:
Neil Griffith's Deconstructing Peterson https://youtu.be/4EZyW_-fo9k 

Prager's brief interview with Peterson where he asks him if he's religious. https://youtu.be/hGSJmMbrFog

transcript_parts.text: hi this is Paul I just wanted to make a
quick video commenting that this time on
a couple of websites but a couple of
other videos about Jordan Peterson that
I saw this morning one of the videos
deconstructing Jordan Peterson by Neil
Griffiths apparently he's a British
author I thought this was one of the
best clearest videos that I've seen on
Peterson that that summarizes his social
and political agenda a couple of things
I you know I noticed right away he
called him an Augustinian which caught
my interest and I thought his his
arguments were were clear and precise I
his illustration of if a Nazi comes up
to you in a canteen I suppose it's like
a British coffee shop canteen and and
wants to talk about and says he's a
neo-nazi how would you respond versus if
someone comes up and says he's a Marxist
how would you respond that's just a
really interesting thought experiment
that that shows kind of the lay of the
land right now in our cultures and I
thought this was there are a lot of
videos that come up talking about Jordan
Peterson I thought this was one of the
one of the better ones and a viewer sent
this recommendation to me and and that
was cool so I really appreciated it
another one that I saw this morning was
was Dennis Prager 'he's interview with
Jordan Peterson it was pretty short and
towards the end of it it was interesting
because Prager asks him are you
religious and I thought the end Peterson
after a moment's pause says yes and I
thought this is this is a great example
of how the place that you're approaching
someone from defines the terms that
you're using I can very under very much
understand why Jordan Peterson would
call himself religious and it's very
interesting though that that's the term
that Prager uses now the hypothesis that
I've been working and presented in a
number of my videos is that the this the
culture war in the West is actually a
war between two civil religions and both
of these civil religions are in a sense
Christian heresies they are they are
reduced there I don't know if they reach
the level of ideology but they are there
Christian heresies and so part of the
argument that that that I think Sam
Harris and others are making who are who
would be not religious is that the
ascendant morality of what I think is is
fundamentally a a reduction of
Christianity into this oppressor a
Pressy you know it's kind of a it's it's
related to liberation theology it's it's
very much in that stream so that's kind
of the ascendant civil religion in the
West right now and pray very much
embodies the Cold War civil religion and
in the Cold War civil religion where you
were fighting godless communists to be
religious was important and so for
Americans Americans put In God We Trust
and one nation under God into the pledge
of the allegiance at that moment so that
old civil religion in the West
especially in the United States that
took deep root and a lot of American
churches and is still present you know
Flags up in churches and this kind of
thing that you know God in country this
is this is kind of the old-style cold
war civil religion and Praeger very much
embodies that when he says I knew you
were religious but you know I'd like to
say well what do you mean by that prayer
because you mean something by it
and Peterson says yes he's religious but
he means something very different by it
now you and Peterson may very well be
aligned in terms of your some of your
political agenda but but Prager is is
still in some ways fighting the Cold War
and and all of the battles that are in
that so then when Peterson comes up and
he's criticizing Marxism well it makes a
world of sense because Prager is gonna
align with him in that but but this
question of religious I mean part of the
part of the issue that's going on with
the ascendant morality of the new civil
religion on the left is that it's very
much a religion and that's where sam
harris and others come into play and say
hey wait a minute you're hurting science
and you're hurting science on the basis
of the dogmas the religious dogmas that
you're using now these are not
traditional religious dogmas these are
in some senses secular religious dogmas
but they are in fact religious and and
so cragars definition of ok your
religious is a framework that doesn't
really fit the the contemporary
perspective so I saw both of these
videos and I thought they were I thought
they were important again the Neal
Griffiths video I thought it was he just
he just nails things one after another
boom boom boom it puts it in a really
interesting way Prager I think is is
talking to talking to a situation that
went out when the Berlin Wall fell and
when the twin towers fell because
obviously those who attacked the United
States were deeply religious and that
motivated their attack so we need to up
the resolution on that conversation and
ask ourselves ok what do you mean by
religious so there are my thoughts
